data.question: What is the empirical formula of Cu-S-M9?
data.answer: C15H52B40Cu4S4

data.question: At what pressure does the Cu(i) to Cu(0) reduction in Cu-S-M9 occur?
data.answer: The reduction occurs after compression beyond 8 GPa.

data.question: Is the average size of the Cu nanoclusters determined by the size of the starting crystal?
data.answer: False, the average size of the Cu nanoclusters is not determined by the size of the starting crystal but rather by the nucleation density and diffusivity of atomic copper at high pressure.

data.question: What is the role of sulfur in the pressure-driven mechanochemical reaction of Cu-S-M9?
data.answer: Sulfur serves as the reducing agent, forming an oxidized species such as disulfide.

data.question: How does the pressure-driven mechanochemical reaction in Cu-S-M9 differ from its conventional thermochemistry?
data.answer: The pressure-driven mechanochemical reaction leads to the formation of elemental copper, whereas heating Cu-S-M9 to 400 °C under vacuum yields cuprous sulfide instead.

data.question: Does the sterically hindered ligand shell in Cu-S-Ada impede the anisotropic deformation and redox reaction in the Cu–S core?
data.answer: True, the sterically hindered adamantyl ligand shell in Cu-S-Ada impedes the anisotropic deformation and redox reaction in the Cu–S core.

data.question: What is the lattice spacing of face-centred cubic copper observed in Cu-S-M9 after compression to 12 GPa?
data.answer: The lattice spacing observed is 2.08 Å.

data.question: What happens to the Cu-S-M9 structure when compressed beyond 8 GPa?
data.answer: Compression beyond 8 GPa results in missing diffraction peaks, indicating a disordered phase, and at 12 GPa all diffraction peaks related to Cu-S-M9 disappear, indicating irreversible structural change.

data.question: Can the molecular anvil concept be applied to other molecular architectures beyond Cu-S-M9?
data.answer: True, the molecular anvil concept can be extended to other molecular architectures, as demonstrated with silver diamondoidthiolate structures under hydrostatic pressure.

data.question: What computational method was used to confirm the large compressibility difference between the Cu4S4 mechanophore and M9 ligands in Cu-S-M9?
data.answer: Density Functional Theory (DFT) computations were used to confirm the large compressibility difference.

data.question: What experimental technique was used to examine the valence change of copper in Cu-S-M9 as a function of pressure?
data.answer: In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to examine the valence change of copper.

data.question: What is the significance of the absence of satellite peaks in the Cu 2p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of compressed Cu-S-M9?
data.answer: The absence of satellite peaks indicates that copper is in the zero valence state (Cu(0)) after compression, excluding the formation of Cu(ii) species.

data.question: Does the compression of Cu-S-M9 to 12 GPa result in the formation of elemental copper nanoclusters?
data.answer: True, compression of Cu-S-M9 to 12 GPa results in the formation of elemental copper nanoclusters.

data.question: What is the role of the adamantyl groups in the mechanochemical reactivity of Cu-S-Ada under hydrostatic pressure?
data.answer: The adamantyl groups in Cu-S-Ada, being in van der Waals contact, impede relative movement and deformation of the Cu–S mechanophore, thus hindering the redox reaction.

data.question: How does the pressure threshold behavior of Cu-S-M9 relate to its structural changes observed via in situ XRD?
data.answer: The pressure threshold behavior of Cu-S-M9, with elemental copper observed only after compression beyond 8 GPa, relates to the structural changes where compression beyond 8 GPa results in missing diffraction peaks and a disordered phase.

data.question: Is the formation of elemental copper in Cu-S-M9 under hydrostatic pressure a reversible process?
data.answer: False, the formation of elemental copper in Cu-S-M9 under hydrostatic pressure is not reversible, as indicated by the irreversible structural change and the formation of elemental copper nanoclusters.

data.question: What computational results support the reduction of Cu(i) to Cu(0) in Cu-S-M9 under hydrostatic pressure?
data.answer: DFT computations showing the anisotropic deformation of the Cu4S4 core and the electron transfer from sulfur to copper support the reduction of Cu(i) to Cu(0) under hydrostatic pressure.

data.question: What experimental evidence confirms the mechanochemical inertness of Cu-S-Ada up to 20 GPa?
data.answer: In situ XRD showing no amorphization and EDS revealing both copper and sulfur in the composition of Cu-S-Ada after compression to 20 GPa confirm its mechanochemical inertness.

data.question: Does the molecular anvil concept demonstrate a new reaction mechanism for mechanochemistry?
data.answer: True, the molecular anvil concept reveals an unexplored reaction mechanism for mechanochemistry through isotropic compression by translating macroscopic isotropic stress into molecular-level anisotropic strain.

data.question: What is the significance of the bending of the S1–Cu1–S2 bond angle in Cu-S-M9 under hydrostatic pressure?
data.answer: The bending of the S1–Cu1–S2 bond angle under hydrostatic pressure significantly stretches the Cu1–S1 and Cu1–S2 bonds, suggesting weakening of the bond strength and facilitating the reduction of Cu(i) to Cu(0).
